title: Alcohol Allergy
author: Jarrod Breeze

sections.heading: What Is an Alcohol Allergy?
content: An alcohol allergy is when your body reacts to alcohol as if it’s a harmful intruder and makes antibodies that try to fight it off. This causes an allergic reaction .
Alcohol allergies are rare, but if you do have one, it doesn’t take much to trigger a reaction. Two teaspoons of wine or a mouthful of beer may be enough.

sections.heading: Alcohol Allergy vs. Intolerance
content: Most people who have a reaction to alcohol aren’t allergic to it. They have an intolerance. They don’t have one of the active enzymes needed to process alcohol -- alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) or aldehyde dehydrogenase (ALDH). This is often called alcohol intolerance.

bullets: Anaphylaxis , which is a severe reaction that can include a rapid, weak pulse, nausea , and vomiting. If you have this, swelling, or trouble breathing , call 911.

sections.heading: Common Food Allergens in Alcoholic Beverages
content: Alcoholic beverages are made from complex mixtures of grains, chemicals, and preservatives that your body needs to break down.
If your body can’t do this well enough, you will have a reaction.
Common allergens in alcoholic beverages include:
Red wine is more likely to cause a reaction than any other alcoholic drink. Beer and whiskey also can cause reactions because both are made from four common allergens: yeast, hops, barley, and wheat.

sections.heading: Alcohol Allergy Risk Factors
content: You may be more likely to have an intolerance to alcohol or allergic symptoms if you:
If you’re taking medication , check with your doctor to see if it’s OK to drink alcohol while you take it.

sections.heading: Alcohol Allergy Diagnosis
content: If you think alcohol is causing your reactions, talk to your doctor. To find out what’s going on, they may do the following:

Your doctor also may recommend that you stop drinking all alcoholic beverages for a while. Then you can start again, perhaps trying just one of your go-to drinks at a time. If the reactions return with specific drinks, then you know which ones cause problems for you.
bullets: Ask you about your family history . Much like allergies, alcohol intolerance can be passed down in families. Your doctor will ask if you have other relatives who have similar problems when they drink.

Do a skin prick test. It can show if you are allergic to an ingredient in alcoholic beverages. You’ll get a prick on your skin with a tiny bit of the substance you may be allergic to. If you are allergic, you’ll get a raised bump in that spot.

sections.heading: Alcohol Allergy Treatment and Prevention
content: Avoiding alcohol is the only sure way to prevent an alcohol-related reaction.

If you do have a reaction, its effects can range from hives, which may not need medical care, to a more serious, possibly life-threatening reaction (anaphylaxis). Anaphylaxis caused by an alcohol allergy is treated the same as with any other type of allergy:
If you have an alcohol allergy, make sure to have epinephrine shots with you at all times and wear a medical ID bracelet that tells health professionals you have an allergy.
bullets: Take a shot of adrenaline (epinephrine) if possible.
